review.title: Proof nets for the Displacement calculus
review.abstract: We present a proof net calculus for the Displacement calculus and show its correctness. This is the first proof net calculus which models the Displacement calculus directly and not by some sort of translation into another formalism. The proof net calculus opens up new possibilities for parsing and proof search with the Displacement calculus.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The displacement calculation was introduced by Morrill, Valent ́ ın & Fadda (2011) as an extension of the Lambek calculation with discontinuous operators that allow the displacement calculation to solve a large number of problems with the Lambek calculation. Examples of the phenomena covered by Morrill et al. (2011) include discontinuous idioms (such as "ring up" and "give the cold shoulder"), quantification scope, extraction (including piping) and gaping. This work extends previous work by Morrill & Fadda (2008), Moot (2014) and Valent ́ ın (2014) and combines the strengths of these different approaches while reducing inconvenience.

sections.heading: 2 The Displacement calculus
sections.text: The representation of the displacement calculation closely follows the natural deduction calculation used by Morrill. "The definition of connectives," according to Morrill, "is a complex concept." (2011) String terms are formed via an imputable, infinite alphabet of variables (for readability). As usual, we used natural words as if they were variables. The type of string term is the number of occurrences of the delimiter "1." I use lowercase letters from Latin. sections.heading: 2.1 Formulas and sorts
sections.text: We have already defined the type of a string term as the number of occurrences of the delimiter constant "1." The type of a formula corresponds to the number of delimiters "1" that occur in its name. That is, a formula of the type n is assigned a string term of the form a0 + 1 +. + 1 + an (with all ai of the type 0 according to our notation convention). For a given grammar, its signature defines the grade of all atomic formulas occurring in grammar. We assume that the atomic formulas s, n, np, pp are assigned a grade 0 (some other atomic formulas, such as inf if they are used for Dutch verb clusters, have a grade 1). Table 1 shows how to calculate the type of complex formulas. All subformulas of a formula are assigned to one variety, so that if we calculate s (C / B) on the basis of its input formula, we obtain a type (C).

sections.heading: 3 Proof nets
sections.text: One of the objectives of proofreading in typological grammars is to list all possible measurements for a given sentence. The bureaucratic aspects of the subsequent proofreading make it difficult to use the subsequent calculation directly for this purpose, since the subsequent calculation allows for a large number of insignificant rule permutations. A somewhat better situation for the natural deduction is that the correction rules correspond directly to steps in the meaning composition, although there are still a large number of possible rule permutations for the • E and • KE rules. Correction networks are a way to present evidence that eliminates the "bureaucratic" aspects of subsequent corrections and simplifies the product rules of the Lambek calculation for the natural deduction. One of Morrill's open questions (2011) is whether the proofreading calculation has a correction calculation for the postponement.

sections.heading: 3.1 Links
sections.text: Figures 3 and 4 show the linkages for displacement calculation structures. Each linkage connects three formulas to a central node. The formulas written above the central node of a linkage are the premises of the linkage, the formulas written below are its conclusions. The linear order of both the premises and the conclusions of a linkage is important. We distinguish between Par linkages, where the central node is filled in black, and tensor linkages, where the central node is not filled (this is the familiar distinction between tensor / par of multiplicative linear logic). Par nodes are further distinguished by an arrow pointing to the main formula of the linkage.

sections.heading: 3.2 Proof structures
sections.text: A structure of evidence is a set of formulas and a set of linkages such as these. 1. Each linkage represents one of the linkages presented in Figures 3 and 4 (for specific values of A, B, C and k), 2. Each formula is the precondition for at most one linkage, 3. Each formula is the conclusion of at most one linkage. Formulas that are not the conclusion of a linkage are the hypotheses of the structure of evidence (the word "conclusion" is overloaded: we are talking about conclusions of evidence, conclusions of linkages and conclusions of evidence structures; if the intended use of the context is clear, I will use the word "conclusion" without further qualification). Entries of a structure of evidence are its hypotheses and the active conclusions of its linkages (i.e., the conclusions of all Par linkages in the structure of evidence are, except the implications, the arrow).

sections.heading: 3.3 Abstract Proof Structures
sections.text: The general strategy we follow to define a correctness criterion for evidence constructions is as follows: We first simplify some of the information that is irrelevant to deciding correctness in order to obtain abstract evidence constructions, then specify the correctness state of these abstract evidence constructions, using a graphic criterion that generalizes the evidence constants of the Lambek calculation from Moot & Puite (2002). A single vertex is a tensor tree, and a tensor tree is a connected, acyclic structure of tensor associations (to be more precise, the underlying undirected graph must be acyclic and connected). sections.heading: 4 Extension to Other Connectives
sections.text: One of the advantages of the current calculation is that it easily extends to other connectors, such as the connectors / brackets by Morrill et al. (2011, Chapter 5) (although addressing parasitic gaps in Section 5.5 would require a significant complication of the theory of evidence).The synthetic connectors by Morrill et al. (2011) require us to expand our methodology somewhat: as it is currently formulated, the proof-net calculation generates a single comb for each proof mesh. If we add the synthetic connectors, we can introduce a separator marker in a way that is only partially specified by the premise of the rule. For example, the condensation of (the widest) split A shown below is the set of strings that are achieved by inserting a separator symbol anywhere in front of other separator symbols (if any), and thus does not yield a unique contraction for this introduction rule.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We have presented a proof-net calculation for the postponement calculation and demonstrated its correctness. This is the first proof-net calculation that directly models the postponement calculation and not through any translation into another formalism. Proof-net calculation opens up new possibilities for analysis and evidence-gathering with the postponement calculation.

2 The Displacement calculus The presentation of the Displacement calculus closely follows the natural deduction calculus used by Morrill et al. (2011). String terms are built over a countably infinite alphabet of variables (for readability, we will often used natural language words as if they were variables), a special separator symbol “1”, where string concatenation is denoted by “+” (a binary, associative infix operator on string terms).

As an example, following Morrill et al. (2011), we can assign a discontinuous lexical entry like “give the cold shoulder” the lexical formula (np \ s) ↑> np and string term gave+ 1+ the+ cold+ shoulder (of the required sort 1).

However, this system uses a rather large set of structural rules and these rules are defined modulo equivalence classes, which makes their use in existing multimodal theorem provers (Moot 2007) difficult.

Combs play the same role as tensor trees do for Moot & Puite (2002): they allow us to go back a forth between sequents Γ ⊢ C and combs with premisses Γ and conclusion C.

NPhardness follows from NP-completeness of the Lambek calculus (Pentus 2006) and we can show it is in NP since we can verify in polynomial time whether or not a candidate proof (that is, a proof structure) in the Displacement calculus is a proof (that is, a proof net).

4 Extension to Other Connectives One of the benefits of the current calculus is that it extends easily to other connectives, such as the unary/bracket connectives of Morrill (2011, Chapter 5) (although incorporating the treatment of parasitic gapping of Section 5.5 would require a considerable complication of the proof theory). The synthetic connectives of Morrill et al. (2011) require us to extend our methodology somewhat: as currently formulated the proof net calculus produces a single comb for each proof net.

These discontinuous connectives allow the Displacement calculus to solve a large number of problems with the Lambek calculus. Examples of the phenomena treated by Morrill et al. (2011) include discontinuous idioms (such as “ring up” and “give the cold shoulder”), quantifier scope, extraction (including pied-piping) and gapping. This paper extends earlier work by Morrill & Fadda (2008), Moot (2014) and Valent́ın (2014), combining the strengths of these different approaches while at the same time diminishing the inconveniences. Notably, it is the first proof net calculus which does not operate by translation into some other logic, but provides proof nets for the Displacement calculus directly.
